summary: This document is a forwarded email containing a news article reporting that Attorney General Bill Barr will not recuse himself from the federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein, but will recuse himself from an internal DOJ probe into Labor Secretary Alex Acosta's role in Epstein's previous non-prosecution deal. It clarifies confusion over Barr's earlier recusal statements.

persons.name: Bill Barr
persons.role: Attorney General of the United States
persons.context: Subject of the article; decided not to recuse himself from the federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein, but will recuse himself from the internal DOJ review of the prior non-prosecution deal.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The financier facing new federal criminal prosecution for sexually abusing dozens of underage girls from 2002 to 2005.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: As then-U.S. Attorney in Miami, he signed off on a controversial no-prosecution deal for Epstein a decade prior; subject of an internal DOJ probe from which Barr recused himself.

connections.description: Barr, as Attorney General, maintained oversight of the federal prosecution of Epstein, deciding not to recuse himself from that case.
Barr recused himself from the internal Justice Department probe into Acosta's involvement in Epstein's prior non-prosecution deal.
As then-U.S. Attorney, Acosta approved a controversial no-prosecution deal for Epstein in the mid-2000s regarding the Florida investigation.

Barr joined the law firm Kirkland & Ellis in 2009, which had previously represented Epstein in 2008. This prior association was the basis for his recusal from the review of the earlier Epstein matter.

events.title: Barr's Recusal Decision Announced
events.description: Attorney General Bill Barr announces he will not recuse himself from the federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein in Manhattan, but will recuse himself from the internal DOJ probe into Alex Acosta's role in the prior non-prosecution deal.

events.title: Barr's Initial Recusal Statement
events.description: Barr tells reporters he is recused from the Epstein matter due to his prior association with the law firm Kirkland & Ellis, which had represented Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Investigation in Florida
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was being investigated in Florida for alleged conduct involving underage girls; he was represented by the law firm Kirkland & Ellis.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Deal
events.description: Then-U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta signs off on a controversial no-prosecution deal for Jeffrey Epstein regarding the Florida investigation.

events.title: Alleged Abuse Period
events.description: Epstein is accused of sexually abusing dozens of underage girls during this period at his residences in Manhattan and Palm Beach, Florida.

keyFacts: Attorney General Bill Barr decided not to recuse himself from the federal criminal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein being handled by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.
Barr did recuse himself from the internal Justice Department probe into Labor Secretary Alex Acosta's role in approving Epstein's controversial non-prosecution deal a decade earlier.

Barr's prior association with the law firm Kirkland & Ellis (which represented Epstein in 2008) was the basis for his recusal from the review of the earlier Florida matter, not from the new prosecution.
Epstein is accused of sexually abusing dozens of underage girls from 2002 to 2005 at his residences in Manhattan and Palm Beach.
Democratic members of Congress and presidential candidates were demanding Acosta's resignation due to his role in the prior Epstein non-prosecution deal.
